7. Ban assault weapons

In Massachusetts, the sale and possession of assault weapons have been permanently banned since 2004. 

Every state should do this.

6. Get the data

One of my bills, S.834, will give the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention $60 million to fund gun violence research. Research has effectively halted over the past two decades because of a Republican appropriations rider called the Dickey amendment.

5. Store guns safely

In Massachusetts, gun owners are required to keep their guns safely secured in a locked container or equipped with a tamper-resistant lock.

Every state should do this.

4. Regulate dealers

#MA is considering a law to require private sales to be completed at licensed dealers. In MA, dealers are required to verify a purchaser‚Äôs license, conduct a background check for every sale, and maintain a record of all sales to share with law enforcement.

3. Protect consumers

In Massachusetts, manufacturing, safety and marketing standards for guns are strictly regulated. 

Every state should do this.

2. Protect the vulnerable

Massachusetts is considering enacting an Extreme Risk Protective Order law to allow families and police to remove guns from high-risk homes. 

Every state should do this.

1. Empower local communities

In Massachusetts, if anyone wants to purchase a gun, they must obtain a license. Obtaining a license requires approval from the local chief of police, which typically includes an in-person interview. 

Every state should do this.

America is a nation of immigrants built and fueled by communities coming to our shores to create better lives. We take in the tired, the poor, the huddled masses. Our country is enriched by diversity & we believe that the American Dream is not determined by where you were born.

Right here, right now we could pass a bill to protect these young immigrants. But instead, the Republicans decided to use #Dreamers as a bargaining chip in budget negotiations. This is shameful. It is immoral. It is a national tragedy.

#Dreamers are young people like Estefany, who study, who serve, who work, and who live next-door to us every single day. They are our friends, our neighbors, and our loved ones. They are not ‚Äútoo lazy‚Äù. They are not ‚Äúbad hombres‚Äù. They are some of our best and our brightest.

As Estefany put it, ‚ÄúAfter so many tears and sleepless nights, it felt like all my hard work was being thrown away.‚Äù But Estefany is a fighter and she is not giving up on her college education or a career. I know she will succeed if she is just given the chance.

Estefany is now attending UMass Boston, where she is pursuing a degree in International Relations and a minor in public policy. So, it sounds like a happy ending. But sadly, it is not. On Estefany‚Äôs first day as a freshman at UMass Boston, @realDonaldTrump repealed #DACA.
Her work ethic and desire to deserve her family‚Äôs sacrifices were what motivated Estefany and got her through the many hardships that come with being undocumented ‚Äì fear, uncertainty, anxiety.

Estefany was overjoyed to be reunited with her mother, who had come to the United States a few years before the rest of the family. Estefany was grateful for the opportunity. she was given and did not want to squander it.
She came to the United States at nine years old to escape violence in El Salvador. She was brought here by her grandmother along with her two sisters and a baby cousin.
I would like take a moment to speak about one of these Massachusetts #Dreamers who benefited from #DACA. Her name is Estefany.

#DACA created security and opportunity for hundreds of thousands of young #Dreamers, allowing them to live and work in our great nation without the threat of deportation. So what DACA really stands for is Deserving A Chance in America.

#Dreamers know no other home than the United States. And many of them have spent their lives in limbo, identifying as Americans but lacking legal status and under the constant threat of being sent back to countries that are completely foreign to them.
